dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, B, has Bitcoin really lived up to its promise of financial freedom, or is it just, uh, another speculative bubble that's kinda, like, fizzled out? I mean, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, B, has Bitcoin really lived up to its promise of financial freedom, or is it just, uh, another speculative bubble that's kinda, like, fizzled out? I mean, honestly.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, A, that's not even a question. It completely failed its original vision. It's, like, the ultimate irony.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, A, that's not even a question. It completely failed its original vision. It's, like, the ultimate irony.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Failed? Come on. Satoshi Nakamoto buried that message about banks collapsing right there in the Genesis block! He was, uh, warning us about trusting traditional finance.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Failed? Come on. Satoshi Nakamoto buried that message about banks collapsing right there in the Genesis block! He was, uh, warning us about trusting traditional finance.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Buried within the code of his Genesis block, Nakamoto embedded a reminder of what happens when too much trust is placed in banks. It was a headline from a British newspaper announcing the imminent bailout of the financial institutions following their collapse in 2008 and 2009: The Times 03/Jan/2009 Chancellor On Brink of Second Bailout for Banks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And now who's exploring blockchain? JPMorgan. IBM. Cargill. The exact banks and corporations Satoshi was, like, railing against. It's a cruel irony, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And now who's exploring blockchain? JPMorgan. I B M. Cargill. The exact banks and corporations Satoshi was, like, railing against. It's a cruel irony, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In fact in a bit cruel irony, some of the most enthusiastic supporters and co-opters of blockchain technology today are those same big companies, ranging from IBM and Cargill to JPMorgan, that early bitcoin believers were rallying against.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But it forced them to adapt! Before that, it was just programmers, um, idealists. It built something from nothing, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it forced them to adapt! Before that, it was just programmers, um, idealists. It built something from nothing, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For the first five years or so, bitcoin largely went unnoticed, appealing to a fringe group of programmers and libertarian idealists.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, a "fringe group" for five years. Then it became, uh, pure speculation. $20,000 a coin, then thousands of worthless tokens, billions in losses.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, a fringe group for five years. Then it became, uh, pure speculation. twenty thousand dollars a coin, then thousands of worthless tokens, billions in losses.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the end of 2017, the frenzy in cryptocurrency speculation peaked with bitcoin at $20,000 and produced thousands of worthless cryptocurrency tokens and investor losses in the billions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's just market volatility! It's still a decentralized alternative. It’s, um, democratizing wealth, putting power in people’s hands.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's just market volatility! It's still a decentralized alternative. It's, um, democratizing wealth, putting power in people's hands.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Democratizing? Or just creating another, uh, casino? Remember Mt. Gox? Silk Road? Financial freedom, really?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Democratizing? Or just creating another, uh, casino? Remember Mt. Gox? Silk Road? Financial freedom, really?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The nascent technology has been plagued by infamous scandals like the FBIs shuttering of underground bitcoin-fueled drug and contraband marketplace Silk Road in 2013 and the $450 million hacking of cryptocurrency exchange Mt. Gox in 2014.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Those were early growing pains! You can't, like, dismiss the entire movement because of a few bad actors. The underlying tech is revolutionary.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Those were early growing pains! You can't, like, dismiss the entire movement because of a few bad actors. The underlying tech is revolutionary.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Revolutionary, sure. But the spirit? The one about escaping central control? Now we have Facebook announcing Libra, China doing its own thing. That's, like, the opposite of decentralization.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Revolutionary, sure. But the spirit? The one about escaping central control? Now we have Facebook announcing Libra, China doing its own thing. That's, like, the opposite of decentralization.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: June 18, 2019 Facebook announces libra, a cryptocurrency partially backed by dollars. China announces its own crypto.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, that's them responding to the threat! It proves how, um, powerful the idea is. It's still early days!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, that's them responding to the threat! It proves how, um, powerful the idea is. It's still early days!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Early days where the biggest players are the ones who, uh, initially mocked it? Bitcoin's ascendance wasn't without setbacks, A. Billions lost. It's not the freedom dream.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Early days where the biggest players are the ones who, uh, initially mocked it? Bitcoin's ascendance wasn't without setbacks, A. Billions lost. It's not the freedom dream.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The ascendance of bitcoin has not been without its setbacks. ... At the end of 2017, the frenzy in cryptocurrency speculation peaked with bitcoin at $20,000 and produced thousands of worthless cryptocurrency tokens and investor losses in the billions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It absolutely is! It's changing how banks, uh, corporations operate. It's pushing them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It absolutely is! It's changing how banks, uh, corporations operate. It's pushing them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A budding ecosystem has arisen, powered by new computer languages and breakthroughs in cryptography that is only now starting to change the way banks, corporations and governments operate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Or they're just, uh, co-opting it. Like a new product line. It's not a revolution if the, um, revolutionaries end up working for the empire.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or they're just, uh, co-opting it. Like a new product line. It's not a revolution if the, um, revolutionaries end up working for the empire.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In fact in a bit cruel irony, some of the most enthusiastic supporters and co-opters of blockchain technology today are those same big companies, ranging from IBM and Cargill to JPMorgan, that early bitcoin believers were rallying against.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's such a cynical take! It's, like, totally missing the point of the whole movement.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's such a cynical take! It's, like, totally missing the point of the whole movement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The point got, uh, lost in all that speculation, I think. It became just another way to make money for the people already in power.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The point got, uh, lost in all that speculation, I think. It became just another way to make money for the people already in power.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, it's still about, um, a new paradigm. You're just, like, stuck in the past.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, it's still about, um, a new paradigm. You're just, like, stuck in the past.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, I'm looking at the present, A. And the present looks suspiciously like the financial system we started with, just with, uh, a new coat of paint.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, I'm looking at the present, A. And the present looks suspiciously like the financial system we started with, just with, uh, a new coat of paint.
